title: Autumn Leaves
analysis:
Autumn Leaves is the quintessential jazz standard for learning ii-V-I progressions in both major and minor keys. The A sections feature a clear pattern: minor ii-V-I (Am7b5 - D7 - Gm) alternating with major ii-V-I (Cm7 - F7 - Bbmaj7). This makes it the perfect vehicle for practicing the most fundamental chord progression in jazz.

The harmony moves through two closely related keys: Bb major and G minor (relative major/minor). This diatonic relationship means the same pool of notes works over much of the tune, making it accessible for beginners while offering depth for advanced players through reharmonization.

suggested_scales.F7: F Mixolydian or F Altered (for tension)
suggested_scales.D7: D Mixolydian, D Altered, or D HW Diminished
suggested_scales.Gm: G Dorian or G Melodic Minor

title: All The Things You Are
analysis:
Considered one of the most harmonically sophisticated standards, ATTYA modulates through multiple key centers. The A sections move from Ab major to C major (via a deceptive resolution), while the second A starts in Eb and modulates to G major. The bridge moves to G major then E major before returning.

The key insight is that each section is built on ii-V-I progressions, just in different keys. If you can hear the ii-V-I motion, the tune becomes navigable despite all the key changes. This is the standard that separates beginners from intermediate players.
common_substitutions: Tritone subs on all dominant chords
notable_recordings: Sonny Rollins — 'A Night at the Village Vanguard' (1957)
Ella Fitzgerald — 'Ella Fitzgerald Sings the Jerome Kern Song Book' (1963)

title: Blue Bossa
analysis:
Blue Bossa is one of the most-called tunes at jazz jam sessions and an ideal introduction to Latin jazz. The 16-bar form is short and manageable. The A section stays in C minor with a clear minor ii-V-i (Dm7b5 - G7b9 - Cm7). The B section modulates briefly to Db major (a half-step up) via Ebm7 - Ab7 - Dbmaj7, then returns to C minor.

The Db major modulation is the only 'tricky' part — everything else is in C minor. This makes Blue Bossa the perfect first tune for practicing minor key improvisation and navigating a simple modulation.

suggested_scales.G7b9: G HW Diminished or G Altered

title: Stella by Starlight
analysis:
Stella by Starlight is a masterpiece of chromatic jazz harmony. The progression constantly moves through different key centers via ii-V patterns, requiring the improviser to navigate quick modulations.

Key harmonic features: The tune begins with a ii-V in D minor (Em7b5-A7b9) but deceptively resolves to Cm7 instead, immediately creating harmonic tension. The Ab7#11 in measure 8 functions as a tritone substitute. The bridge visits Bb major, D minor, then Eb major before resolving back.

This is a tune that rewards deep harmonic study. Every chord change has purpose and logic.

suggested_scales.A7b9: A Altered or A HW Diminished

title: So What
analysis:
So What is the landmark modal jazz composition from Miles Davis's 'Kind of Blue' (1959), the best-selling jazz album of all time. With only two chords — Dm7 for the A sections and Ebm7 for the bridge — it represents a radical departure from the complex bebop harmony of the 1950s.

The simplicity is deceptive. With no chord changes to outline, the improviser must create interest through:
- Melodic invention (you can't rely on chord tones resolving)
- Rhythmic creativity
- Dynamic variation
- Modal color (exploring the full palette of D Dorian / Eb Dorian)

The 'So What chord' (a quartal voicing: D-G-C-F-A) voiced by Bill Evans on the original recording became one of the most iconic sounds in jazz. Guitarists frequently use this voicing.
common_substitutions: Not applicable — the point is modal simplicity

suggested_scales.Dm7: D Dorian (primary), D Minor Pentatonic, D Melodic Minor (for color)

notable_recordings: Miles Davis — 'Kind of Blue' (1959, THE recording)
John Coltrane — his solo on the original is a masterclass
Bill Evans Trio — the piano intro is iconic
